In an editorial in that issue was the following:
"The NEWS-LETTER wishes on behalf of the students to thank
the Lacrosse Team of 1902 for their generous offer. Such spirit is surely an answer to the
mistaken theory that spirit is wanting at Hopkins. The class teams last year were recognized
as one of the reasons for the successful lacrosse year. They.not only aroused interest, but
developed material. Without interest and a well-trained scrub, a team is seriously handicapped. Let us hope that 1902's enthusiasm will be well repaid in the shape of another championship team in 1907!"
Their enthusiasm was repaid! But the class games, as one may see by their letter, satisfied the Team of 1902 as little as they did many men in the University. Their offer is generous
and we all thank them for their renewed interest and enthusiasm, and the best way to show
our gratitude is to get up a dandy series of class games—and—to be the championship team
of 1908!

were glad to see lately a notice posted on the bulletin board of a
meeting of the "Hopkins' Night Committee." This is good news.
The NEWS-LETTER has been asking for a Hopkins' Night repeatedly,
and at last we are going to have one. We only wish it could be
arranged for "The Red Mill." Were we a frivolous paper we would
say, "Don't miss seeing 'The Red Mill'—Hopkins' Night or no
Hopkins' Night!" But as we are not a frivolous but an intensely
sober paper, we will say nothing at all about it. (See page nine.)

The NEWS-LETTER announces with regret the resignation of Messrs. Hermann J.
Hughes and Lawrence Melville Riddle from the Board of Editors. Mr. Hughes has made a
very successful Business Manager and a very useful member of the Board. He will be greatly
missed. Mr. Riddle, too, has done good work for the paper and we trust that after his enforced resignation, he will continue to show as much interest in the welfare of the paper as he
has in the past.
On account of these resignations several changes have been made in the positions of the
Editors. Mr. Pedrick, who has been a member of the Board since the Fall of 1906, becomes
Assistant Editor-in-Chief; and Mr. Corner, recently elected to the Board, becomes News-Editor.
We announce with pleasure the election of Mr. J. Hamilton Owens and Mr. Alan C.
Woods as Assistant News-Editors of the NEWS-14iTTER.
BALTIMORE, Mn.,

December 13, 1907.

MR. SAMUEL C. CHEW, JR.,
Editor-in-Chief of the NEWS-LETTER,
Johns Hopkins University:
Dear Sir:—Once again the time is here for the Undergraduates to get ready to be
rounded into shape so that the Johns Hopkins University may carry off the third successive
Lacrosse Championship.
Now we know that there are many men who think it a hopeless task for a beginner to
make the 'Varsity team the first year, and thus have not the necessary ambition to come out
and at least try for the same. They seem to forget that to make a place on the team at all, a
beginning must be made some time. It is for these and others who have acquired a smattering
of the game at the prep schools that the inter-class games have been arranged. It was done
with the hope that those who are not willing to work for a place on the first team and think it

4

THE NEWS-LETTER.

ought to go with their prep school certificate, may be induced to practice for these class teams,
and thus have the love for the games so instilled in them that they will aim higher and be
seized with a desire to work for the 'Varsity. For no doubt the doctrine of our day that "a
man who will not work need not apply," still holds good with the team of today. Lacrosse
ability with no sound effort behind it is of no use to a team, but only retards it.
To be frank, the inter-class series of last Spring did not produce the results which had
been expected of them. This was due, in a large measure, to the fact that the Freshmen
thought the Juniors had a sure thing, and hence they did not deem it worth their while to
practice for the games. This element does not exist this year, as from all accounts the
material in the two classes is so evenly matched that only the class putting forth the greater
effort will be able land the trophies.
So, under the circumstances, the Lacrosse Team of 1902 believes that an inter-class
series will be especially successful this season and again offers to donate twelve trophies to the
student body of the Johns Hopkins University, these to be presented to the players of the
team carrying off the palm of victory in two out of a series of three lacrosse games to be played
between the Junior and Freshman Classes.
The conditions governing the contest to be as follows:
First—The parties to the contest shall be twelve players picked from the Junior Class on
one
side; and twelve players picked from the Freshman and Sub-Freshman Classes on the
the
other.
Second—The games may be played on any field the contesting classes may select.
Third—The games are to be played, if possible, in March and up to the middle of April,
and on such dates as not to interfere with the practice of the University Lacrosse Team.
Fourth—Two out of three games must be played.
Fifth—Should any disputes arise between the two classes as to the eligibility of any
student, date and place of games, length of halves, officials, etc., it shall devolve upon a committee consisting of the Captain of the 'Varsity Lrcrosse Team, the Physical Director of the
University and the President of the Board of Governors of the Athletic Association to pass on
such disputes. Whatever decision may be reached by this committee shall be final.
Si.x-th—If it should so happen that two or more men should be called on to fill the same
position, in the same or different games throughout the series, it shall devolve on the class
organization to select the player entitled to receive the prize.
We suggest that the two classes appoint their respective captains at their earliest opportunity, so that these men may see to it that their candidates report to practice with the 'Varsity
squad and thus raise the standard of the class teams.
In conclusion, we beg to say that it pleases us to hear that the Baltimore City College
team has passed successfully through a precarious season and starts in this year with spirit and
enthusiasm. This team should be given every assistance possible, and it seems to us that if
some of our other lacrosse graduates, who have expressed themselves as desirous of giving the
'Varsity team a boost, would inaugurate an inter-class series at the City College, it would
greatly improve and multiply our lacrosse material.
Trusting that you will give this matter your attention in the columns of the NEWSLETTER, and hoping to hear from you that the Undergraduates are ready to play a series of
games under the conditions as suggested above, we remain;
Yours respectfully,.
THE LACROSSE TEAM OF 1902.
A. SWAYNE PUTTS, Allegheny, Pa.
J. ABNER SAYLER, JR., Baltimore.
E. P. BERNinam, Louisville, Ky.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

PERSONAL VANITY.
From the French of Leon Frapie
By

JOHN

ALAN

HAMMON.

At the age of thirty-six, Athanase de
Glidoir, without family and without love
affairs of any serious kind, became frightfully
hypochondriac for no other reason in the
world than because he had nothing to occupy
his mind.
Tall and thin and dressed with a sort of
rectilinear elegance, his fixed maniacal stare
gave him a most unusual appearance. The
thought of suicide began to haunt him and he
formed the habit of walking up and down the
quais from La Concorde to Auteuil, especially
the less frequented ones, and sometimes he
would go down close to the water and sit and
watch it for hours. Having little or no moustache, a long nose and chin, he made one
think instinctively of a despondent crane.
Three evenings in succession he made a trip
to the Pont d'Iena to inspect an iron ring
that was driven high up into the wall near the
bridge for some commercial use or other, and
finding it very much to his taste, he came
back the fourth evening determined to hang
himself from it.
Having gained the water's edge near his
iron ring, he drew from his pocket, with a
certain satisfaction, a soft curtain cord, artistically chosen for the occasion on account of its
red silk outside. Hardly had he begun to
make a noose in it when a shadow moving
nearby attracted his attention, and no wonder,
for a man had just hanged himself from de
Glidoir's chosen ring!
Furious with the anger of a man who finds
someone occupying his seat in a church or a
theatre, he rushed forward and cut the rope
without supporting the man, who fell limply
to the ground with a thump. Athanase bent
over him and began untying the rope from his
neck, but without much gentleness, for the
man's head bumped up and down on the pavement. This manner of procedure seemed to
be the proper one, for the stranger's eyes
opened and his lips moved as though he were
trying to speak. He was conscious apparently
of all that was going on, but unable as yet to
talk.
Athanase profited by the circumstance to

5

speak his mind, so with much angry gesture
he began:
"Has no one any longer any respect for the
rights of others?, Would you be so kind as to
tell me what business you had to hang yourself from 'that particular ring? If you'd had
an ounce of manners, you'd have done it at
home, but obviously, appearances don't bother
you any more thaii other habits of gentlefolk.
Supposing a woman had come along this way,
or some children; a nice spectacle you'd have
made dangling there in the dust (Athanase
was growing poetic). You might at least have
had the decency to put on a light-colored suit
like mine, so they could see you; it would
have been a sort of notice: 'Don't come this
way, I've just hanged myself!'"
The man began to show signs of ability to
reply, so de Glidoir hurried on so as to have
his say out.
"Any person with any taste • whatever
would have jumped into the river, it's far less
trouble and so much more private. The
ostentation of this didn't bother you in the
least though, you just went on and did it your
own way!"
Athanase stood up so as to gain in a hurry,
if necessary, his chosen place. One never
knew what a spoil-sport like this would do.
"What's your name?" he asked the man
whose lips were again moving.
"Bagu."
"Bagu!" I'm not surprised! It's elegance
itself, just like you and your manners!"
Bagu, with his thin face and hungry eyes,
looked like a workman who had been out of
employment for a long time.
"Why suicide, may I ask?"
'Poverty!"
Athanase de Glidoir raised his chin in the
air the least bit in the world:
"Idiot!" he said. "Poverty's no reason for
killing yourself; it's a reason for living, the
best, the only reason! If you possess nothing
it's exactly as though you were just born,
everything is before you to desire, to conquer
and to take. Now the only logical reason for
suicide is riches, because there's no cure for
it. A rich man is a sort of dead-alive person.
He has no destination, nothing to desire,
nothing to discover. At least you have the
excuse of loneliness."

he jumped into bed, after turning the lamp
down low and swallowing an opium pill.
Unfortunately his excitement w or ked
against the narcotic and so after half an hour
he was wide enough awake to hear the door of
his apartment open very softly.
Instantly his desire for death took unto itself wings, and he was seized with a love of
life, so acute that his most insignificant possessions seemed dear past telling. He jumped
out of bed, and as Bagu got to the door of
the room, creeping noiselessly along, he
called out to him:
"Stop! It's I. You recognize me, don't
you? I did think I'd like to die, and it was
awfully kind of you to fall in with my plan,
but I've changed my mind. Get out!"
But Bagu turned up the lamp and advanced
impeturbably. The absinthe drunk after a
long fast, had taken effect, and he loomed up
sinister and formidable. His voice sounded
solemn.
"Oh! yes, I recognize you, but that's not
going to prevent my knifing you."
"What!" cried de Glidoir, backing to the
bed, "but I don't want you to!"
"As if that made any difference," chuckled
Bagu. "Murderers don't usually consult
their—their clients."
He moved a chair quietly to the bed, like a
methodical operator, and taking the knife
from his pocket he opened it without hurry.
De Glidoir shrivelled up in the bed-clothes.
Gibbering with fear he managed to stammer
out:
"Very well, I'll allow you to steal a little
—not much, you understand!"
"I prefer to stick you first," said Bagu in
an even voice, "because otherwise you might
wing me with your gun or call for help—"
Athanase's eyes were starting from his head
and his teeth rattled like dice.
"You'll never be able to find :the money—
here, let me.get up—"
"Oh! don't bother; I've got all the time
there is. I can hunt for it all night if
necessary."
The knife was ready, wide open.
"But reflect what a ghastly crime you are

Bagu looked at him severely, turning the

"I have two children."
"Mercy on us! What next? I've a good
notion to hang you up again with my own
hands! Why this is worse than mere stupidity,
it's a criminal monstrosity, your committing
suicide. Don't you know you belong to your
children, and it's your duty to struggle for
them in every way imaginable?"
De Glidoir pronounced these last words with
the air of one inspired. He had given up all
idea of hanging himself now, possibly from
the fear that he might look like Bagu when it
was done, but a sudden inspiration had come
to him—he would commit suicide by means of
Bagu
This was a happy thought, and quite satisfied his desire for a dramatic exit, and along
with it he could do a stroke of charity. Yes,
indeed, it was a good idea all around.
He helped the man to his feet, and taking
hold of his arm he walked him along slowly,
giving him a little shake every now and then
to complete his resuscitation, talking to him
persuasively all the time.
"You go to the Rue de Prony, number 208.
On the ground floor to the right, a man, lives
who goes to bed every night at nine o'clock,
dead drunk, with his door-key on the outside.
He's rich and you can make a fine haul there,
but I'd begin by cutting his throat if I were
you, because he's a low blackguard with no
sympathy for the poor, and besides, he always
keeps a revolver under his pillow and he's had
alarms put on all his drawers."
They were just passing a cutler's shop, so
Athanase went in and bought him a fine clasp
knife.
"Put that in your pocket," he said to Bagu,
who obeyed him with the impassive stare
of a sleep-walker.
"Let's go to a cafe."
Athenase poured absinthe and seltzer into
the man until you'd have thought he'd burst.
"Now, there you are," he said, leaving
him, "you'd best go directly. Remember
your poor children, and do not hesitate!"

with the tone of authority of a superior person,
speaking to some ignorant insignificant, he
said:
"Monsieur, I possess nothing, it's with me
exactly as though I had just been born, everything is before me,—to desire, to conquer and
to taste—"
De Glidoir gave a hideous grimace which he
fondly believe to be a smile.
"Come, come, Bagu, I'm a good sort of a
chap—"
"You? Why, you're a low blackguard with
no sympathy for the poor!"
"Well, then, take my gold watch. Will
that satisfy you? It's there on the chimneypiece."
With his armed hand Bagu made a dignified
gesture.
"I have children," he said. "I belong to
them."
De Glidoir began to sob.
"I cut you down when you'd hanged yourself, and saved your life! Was ever such ingratitude!"
The same gesture of offended dignity from
Bagu.
"Monsieur," he said, "I am convinced that
I am doing you a service: being rich, you are
a sort of dead-alive person with no destination,
nothing to desire, nothing to discover—Don't
take on so. I won't hurt you much. I know
how to do it, because I've cut ducks' throats
for years."
So saying, Bagu again passed and repassed
the blade over his arm to give it a final edge,
and then stood up.

Athancase, wild with terror and scarcely
knowing what he was doing, cried out in a
loud voice as though it were absolutely necessary for him to know before he died:
"And—your children—are they girls or
boys!"
Bagu stopped sharpening the knife, but he
turned up his sleeve in a business-like way:
"Two girls: Marie and Je'anne."
Athanase, with an idiotic bleat, went on:
"Ah, that's much better than boys!"
"Ye, much better," answered Bagu distantly, rubbing his thumb along the edge of
the blade.

7

"I'm so fond of children," brayed de
Glidoir, squinting at the knife as though his
visitor were about to dispatch a brace of
cherubim for,his consumption.
Bagu shrngged his shoulders approvingly.
'I have their pictures somewhere,' he said.
"I brought them with me to kiss them farewell."
"Oh! do let me see them!" begged de
Glidoir.
"There," said Bagu, taking a small photograph from an inside pocket.
Athanase seized on it and giving an absurdly forced laugh, cried;
"Ah! You said Marie and Jeanne, didn't
you? This must be Marie, the elder. She's
pretty, but Jeanne, she looks like a sly little
piece!"
"She is that!" replied Bagu, beginning to
be interested, "you can ask anyone in the
neighborhood."
"I simply can't take my eyes off them!"
cried de Glidoir, "they're just the kind of
children I adore!"
Bagu gave a deprecating smile and began
again to strop the knife, this time on his
thigh. The gentleman's demonstrations
seemed perfectly natural to him.
"Could you possibly give me this photograph?" asked de Glidoir, with the avidity of
a lover.
Bagu's smile broadened. He was rather
tickled at the idea. "Proud Papa," that sort
of thing. Instantly, though, his expression
changed as though the smile had been stopped
by a ratchet. He stood with his mouth open
like one hypnotized by some terrible, unheard
of difficulty. He looked first at the knife and
then at Athanase; one could'nt give photographs to a dead man.
"I'd like, to," he said in an embarassed
tone, "but—," and he stopped, confused by
the dilemma between which he was caught.
"Oh, come now," said de Glidoir, understanding the situation perfectly. He did not
offer to solve the problem, however, but
studied the picture minutely.
"I've never seen such interesting children's
faces," he went on. `Ah! little Marie—and
Jeanne—really, it,s awfully hard to decide
which—they're both so—!"

8

THE NEWS-LETTER.

He pronounced the words with the deepest
interest and respect. Bagu stood smiling,
pleased and paternal. Then he again grew
grave. What was he to do? He was caught
in a tight place between the poignard and the
portrait. He gave another smile:
"No, Monsieur, you have never seen two
such little beauties,"
Again, he busied himself with the knife.
Whatever was he to do? It was a simple
matter enough to kill this gentleman and
make away with everything he had of any
value, but on the other hand, it seemed a
pity to cut the throat of anyone who had such
obviously good taste.
Finally vanity came out the stronger. He
could not do away with such a keen
appreciator of his children's beauty.
"Very well," he said, "you may keep the
picture."
He closed the knife, put it in his hip pocket
and got up with the air of a casual visitor
taking his leave.
"Ah!" said de Glidoir, embarassed apparently at accepting the gift, "I really hardly
like to deprive you—"
"Oh! don't mention it, don't mention it,"
said Bagu with a wave of his hand.
And in order to cut short these formalities,
he walked toward the door. His role of
father of the two charming daughters made
him the equal of this admiring gentleman
and compelled him to noble manners.
He had forgotten the possibilty of taking
anything of the least value. His poverty was
forgotten and every reality became negligible.
He was enriched to infinity by paternal
vanity.
He went out, his bosom sweling with pride,
making the same gesture of a gentleman
deprecating a trifling service done for another.
Some people passing, were rather astonished
at the grand manner with which he said:
"Not at all! not at all!" as he closed the
door.
A lot is heard 'bout Presidents,
The party's love for Taft;
We wonder if this match will bring
To both an Eppie-Taft.

THE POST-GRAD, THE GIRL AND THE
FOOTBALL GAME.
This "contribution" (of which genus the smallest
is most gratefully, etc.,) was submitted with the
following note:
To the Editor of the NEWS-LliTTER:
Dear Sir:—This is a contribution from one who
is very much interested in the NUN/vs-LATTER—an
M. M. G.
Undergrad, not a Post-Grad.

Whirr-bang! The door-bell had hardly
stopped ringing when the staid old butler
threw open the door and in walked the flurried
and anxious Post-Grad. Staggered by the
shining silver card tray, he lunged into his
pocket with a desperate gasp in search of the
elusive pasteboard. Where on earth was it?
What made the butler smile in that supercilious way? Why, he had had the card as he
came up the steps, and now—and now—good
gracious!—it was in his left hand! The supercilious smile broadened into an open grin,as the
dignified white shirt front bowed him into the
parlor. He stepped gingerly over the slippery
floor, glancing hopelessly at the spindlelegged gilt chairs and remained standing in
the middle of the floor. A deliciously dainty
rustle of silk, the clicking of tiny French
heels on the stair—there she stood in the
doorway, a vision of fur and feathers, her
long, dark cloak in marked contrast with her
delicate pink cheeks.
The Post-Grad took three hasty steps, but
alas!—that slippery floor! The table—the
chair—what COULD he grasp? What—but
now it was too late—his heels slipped, and the
dignified student of philosophy sprawled in a
helpless tangle with the slender legs of the
gilded chair.
At last he arose to his feet and, blushing
furiously, stammered: 'Er—ah—isn't it a
nice day for the game?" The girl, sweetly
ignoring the mishap, but inwardly choking
with laughter, led the way to the door, and
together they walked down the steps and
silently hurried to the car.
"We must be exceedingly early," the PostGrad remarked, as they took their seats.
"Yes," said the girl, "nobody seems to be
going to the game. Who's going to play,
anyhow?"
"Well, you see, er—every year they play,
you know, er —that is, the Freshman and

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Junior contingents choose ah—eleven men to
determine—ah, to decide—I mean to play
football."
"Oh how perfectly lovely! I wish I understood it as well as you do! But, of course,
you have played so often."
"Ah—well; no—that is—not exactly. I
received an injury—ah—during the early—in
the first part of my Freshman year, and have
never—really played since."
"Oh, how terrible!" came the sympathetic
cry.
"Ah, don't worry, not seriously you know
—just ah—only—well you see—I sprained
my little finger—"
Whereupon the girl coughed suddenly and
looked out the window.
After a long and embarassing silence, the
car stopped and the Post-Grad rose.
"Here's where we get out," he said.
"Do we have to walk far?" she asked.
(Ah—er I don't know—I should have inquired more particularily as to the way, but I
think—ah—now I remember—we go over
there.
Together they walked silently across the
road, down the path, and over the bridge.
"I don't see a single soul. We must be
very early—there's no one here at all," and
she looked dolefully, first at the vast stretches
of mud, and then at her mud-bespattered
shoes.
"I will get my tickets out anyhow," and
the serious student extricated the tickets from
the depths of his costume and began to peruse
them slowly. Suddenly he stopped, gasped
and cried,
'What—what day is today?"
``The fifth."
"Well—it's—the—wrong—day."
M. M. G.

ATHLETIC NOTES.
Again has the Lacrosse Team of 1902 come
to the fore and offered to the Junior and Freshman Classes a set of individual trophies to be
contested for by lacrosse teams from those
classes. This is the third year that these
trophies have been offered, and they have been
productive of some excellent games. Last
year the contests were not so interesting as the
year before, when the present Senior Class,
then Freshmen, took the class of 1907 into
camp in the two games played.
The generosity and spirit of the men who
compose the team of 1902 is certainly to be
commended, and it is to be hoped that the
classes this year will show the proper appreciation of such a generous gift. It is a good
showing for the spirit among our alumni,
when, in addition to contributions toward an
athletic field, they can subscribe to foster the
lacrosse spirit at the University. The NEWSLETTER takes great pleasure in thanking the
1902 team for their exceedingly kind offer on
behalf of the students of the University.
The Director of the Gymnasium has undertaken a worthy project, and one in which all
the fellows should heartily co-operate. The
scheme is to supply those who use the shower
baths with clean towels whenever wanted, at
a cost price. He has gotten an appropriation
from the Board of Trustees, and with it will
purchase 1,000 bath towels. Now the plan is
this: Each fellow who wants a towel is to
sign a card and pay a dollar. He may either
pay a dollar in advance, or it may be taken off
his caution money at the end of the year: that
point has not been settled as yet. By paying
this dollar, he is entitled to a clean towel
whenever he may wish it. This privilege will
continue from now until the University
closes. This is an excellent plan, and will
do away with lots of trouble. Instead of
having to bring towels from home, or rent
them from "Jim," a man may have a clean
towel whenever he wishes, at the low cost of
one dollar for five months. This one dollar
represents the cost of laundering. Now, in
order to make this scheme work, there must be
a big crowd in it. There must be at least 100
bathers sign up for the towels. If the plan
works, and it certainly ought if the students

10

THE NEWS-LETTER.

give it the proper backing, Dr. Abercrombie
is to be congratulated, for he will have supplied a long-felt want, and added one more
comfort to the locker room.

LACROSSE TEAM.
The lacrosse season is in full blast, and
soon you will see the usual number of swollen
fingers, and cut heads as a result of practising
in the cage. The prospects for a winning
team are good, but there are several positions
yet to be filled. From time to time the daily
newspapers have come out with fore-casts of
what the line-up will be. To the candidates
let this be said: Pay no attention to what the
papers say, for they are usually far from
right, particularly with regard to Hopkins
teams. There is some time yet before the
first game, and surprises are likely to happen
at any time. Sometimes fellows do not make
the team until the last game, so keep your
nerve with you. Remember the class teams.
If you play on the winning class team, you
will get a fine gold medal. Juniors, you have
not won at lacrosse as yet, and you can't
afford to be beaten by the Freshmen. Freshmen, you were beaten in football, now get
busy and retrieve yourselves by licking the
Juniors in lacrosse. It has been done before,
and can be done again.
This year the Lacrosse League, in addition
to giving a trophy to the winning team, will
give individual trophies to the players on
championship teams. Hopkins must win the
championship, and everybody must do his
best to land that coveted title. Let us see if
the team of 1908 can't be the one to make it
three championships straight.

COTILLON CLUB.
The time for the next Cotillon Club Dance
is almost here, and there are many subscribers
who have not yet paid anything on their dues,
not even for the first dance. This state of
affairs is positively disgraceful. How do you
expect us to give these dances in the proper
style? You do not seem to realize that it
takes ready money to run these dances, and
unless one hundred dollars more is paid up it

will be impossible to give the other two
dances. The Board .of Governors is working
as hard as it possibly can to collect the money,
but it met with very little success before the
Christmas Holidays. Let us hope that it will
be more successful in the New Year. Everyone before Christmas was crying hard times,
but now that it is past and everyone received
lots of money at Christmas, there is no excuse
for not paying.
The Cotillon Club Dances are not supported
by the students as well as they should be. It
used to be that everyone was anxious to
attend the Cotillons, and did not have to be
begged to come. When one remembers that
the Cotillon Club Dances—and there are only
three during the year—are the only social
activity at Hopkins, one ought to feel ashamed
to think that the students have to be beseached
and implored to subscribe to the dances, and
even then enough subscriptions can not be
raised to insure the success of the dances.
The three upper classes are well represented
more or less, but the Freshmen did not make
as good a showing as was expected of them.
Freshmen, it is no excuse to say that you are
too busy, or have too much work, for both of
the remaining dances are on Friday nights.
Another point is that we will not have the
tone of these dances lowered. All the gentlemen are requested to wear either tuxedos or
full dress. We think that only a word on
this subject will be sufficient.
We should like to take this opportunity to
remark upon the lack of interest which is
shown by the chaperons in the dances. There
is always a list of about twenty-five chaperons
on the programs, but usually there are present
only about three or at the most five. These
are generally the same ones and we take
great pleasure in extending to them our
heartiest thanks, and hope that they will continue to take interest in the dances. What a
dreadful plight we should be in, if the few
faithful ones should ever desert us!

the Lacrosse Team of 1902 for their generous offer. Such spirit is surely an answer to the
mistaken theory that spirit is wanting at Hopkins. The class teams last year were recognized

were glad to see lately a notice posted on the bulletin board of a
meeting of the "Hopkins' Night Committee." This is good news.
The NEWS-LETTER has been asking for a Hopkins' Night repeatedly,
and at last we are going to have one. We only wish it could be
arranged for "The Red Mill." Were we a frivolous paper we would
say, "Don't miss seeing 'The Red Mill'—Hopkins' Night or no
Hopkins' Night!" But as we are not a frivolous but an intensely
sober paper, we will say nothing at all about it. (See page nine.)

The NEWS-LETTER announces with regret the resignation of Messrs. Hermann J.
Hughes and Lawrence Melville Riddle from the Board of Editors. Mr. Hughes has made a
very successful Business Manager and a very useful member of the Board. He will be greatly
missed. Mr. Riddle, too, has done good work for the paper and we trust that after his enforced resignation, he will continue to show as much interest in the welfare of the paper as he
has in the past.
On account of these resignations several changes have been made in the positions of the
Editors. Mr. Pedrick, who has been a member of the Board since the Fall of 1906, becomes
Assistant Editor-in-Chief; and Mr. Corner, recently elected to the Board, becomes News-Editor.
We announce with pleasure the election of Mr. J. Hamilton Owens and Mr. Alan C.
Woods as Assistant News-Editors of the NEWS-14iTTER.
BALTIMORE, Mn.,

December 13, 1907.

MR. SAMUEL C. CHEW, JR.,
Editor-in-Chief of the NEWS-LETTER,
Johns Hopkins University:
Dear Sir:—Once again the time is here for the Undergraduates to get ready to be
rounded into shape so that the Johns Hopkins University may carry off the third successive
Lacrosse Championship.
Now we know that there are many men who think it a hopeless task for a beginner to
make the 'Varsity team the first year, and thus have not the necessary ambition to come out
and at least try for the same. They seem to forget that to make a place on the team at all, a
beginning must be made some time. It is for these and others who have acquired a smattering
of the game at the prep schools that the inter-class games have been arranged. It was done
with the hope that those who are not willing to work for a place on the first team and think it

4

THE NEWS-LETTER.

ought to go with their prep school certificate, may be induced to practice for these class teams,
and thus have the love for the games so instilled in them that they will aim higher and be
seized with a desire to work for the 'Varsity. For no doubt the doctrine of our day that "a
man who will not work need not apply," still holds good with the team of today. Lacrosse
ability with no sound effort behind it is of no use to a team, but only retards it.
To be frank, the inter-class series of last Spring did not produce the results which had
been expected of them. This was due, in a large measure, to the fact that the Freshmen
thought the Juniors had a sure thing, and hence they did not deem it worth their while to
practice for the games. This element does not exist this year, as from all accounts the
material in the two classes is so evenly matched that only the class putting forth the greater
effort will be able land the trophies.
So, under the circumstances, the Lacrosse Team of 1902 believes that an inter-class
series will be especially successful this season and again offers to donate twelve trophies to the
student body of the Johns Hopkins University, these to be presented to the players of the
team carrying off the palm of victory in two out of a series of three lacrosse games to be played
between the Junior and Freshman Classes.
The conditions governing the contest to be as follows:
First—The parties to the contest shall be twelve players picked from the Junior Class on
one
side; and twelve players picked from the Freshman and Sub-Freshman Classes on the
the
other.
Second—The games may be played on any field the contesting classes may select.
Third—The games are to be played, if possible, in March and up to the middle of April,
and on such dates as not to interfere with the practice of the University Lacrosse Team.
Fourth—Two out of three games must be played.
Fifth—Should any disputes arise between the two classes as to the eligibility of any
student, date and place of games, length of halves, officials, etc., it shall devolve upon a committee consisting of the Captain of the 'Varsity Lrcrosse Team, the Physical Director of the
University and the President of the Board of Governors of the Athletic Association to pass on
such disputes. Whatever decision may be reached by this committee shall be final.
Si.x-th—If it should so happen that two or more men should be called on to fill the same
position, in the same or different games throughout the series, it shall devolve on the class
organization to select the player entitled to receive the prize.
We suggest that the two classes appoint their respective captains at their earliest opportunity, so that these men may see to it that their candidates report to practice with the 'Varsity
squad and thus raise the standard of the class teams.
In conclusion, we beg to say that it pleases us to hear that the Baltimore City College
team has passed successfully through a precarious season and starts in this year with spirit and
enthusiasm. This team should be given every assistance possible, and it seems to us that if
some of our other lacrosse graduates, who have expressed themselves as desirous of giving the
'Varsity team a boost, would inaugurate an inter-class series at the City College, it would
greatly improve and multiply our lacrosse material.
Trusting that you will give this matter your attention in the columns of the NEWSLETTER, and hoping to hear from you that the Undergraduates are ready to play a series of
games under the conditions as suggested above, we remain;
Yours respectfully,.
THE LACROSSE TEAM OF 1902.

PERSONAL VANITY.
From the French of Leon Frapie
By

JOHN

ALAN

HAMMON.

At the age of thirty-six, Athanase de
Glidoir, without family and without love
affairs of any serious kind, became frightfully
hypochondriac for no other reason in the
world than because he had nothing to occupy
his mind.
Tall and thin and dressed with a sort of
rectilinear elegance, his fixed maniacal stare
gave him a most unusual appearance. The
thought of suicide began to haunt him and he
formed the habit of walking up and down the
quais from La Concorde to Auteuil, especially
the less frequented ones, and sometimes he
would go down close to the water and sit and
watch it for hours. Having little or no moustache, a long nose and chin, he made one
think instinctively of a despondent crane.
Three evenings in succession he made a trip
to the Pont d'Iena to inspect an iron ring
that was driven high up into the wall near the
bridge for some commercial use or other, and
finding it very much to his taste, he came
back the fourth evening determined to hang
himself from it.
Having gained the water's edge near his
iron ring, he drew from his pocket, with a
certain satisfaction, a soft curtain cord, artistically chosen for the occasion on account of its
red silk outside. Hardly had he begun to
make a noose in it when a shadow moving
nearby attracted his attention, and no wonder,
for a man had just hanged himself from de
Glidoir's chosen ring!
Furious with the anger of a man who finds
someone occupying his seat in a church or a
theatre, he rushed forward and cut the rope
without supporting the man, who fell limply
to the ground with a thump. Athanase bent
over him and began untying the rope from his
neck, but without much gentleness, for the
man's head bumped up and down on the pavement. This manner of procedure seemed to
be the proper one, for the stranger's eyes
opened and his lips moved as though he were
trying to speak. He was conscious apparently
of all that was going on, but unable as yet to
talk.
Athanase profited by the circumstance to

5

speak his mind, so with much angry gesture
he began:
"Has no one any longer any respect for the
rights of others?, Would you be so kind as to
tell me what business you had to hang yourself from 'that particular ring? If you'd had
an ounce of manners, you'd have done it at
home, but obviously, appearances don't bother
you any more thaii other habits of gentlefolk.
Supposing a woman had come along this way,
or some children; a nice spectacle you'd have
made dangling there in the dust (Athanase
was growing poetic). You might at least have
had the decency to put on a light-colored suit
like mine, so they could see you; it would
have been a sort of notice: 'Don't come this
way, I've just hanged myself!'"
The man began to show signs of ability to
reply, so de Glidoir hurried on so as to have
his say out.
"Any person with any taste • whatever
would have jumped into the river, it's far less
trouble and so much more private. The
ostentation of this didn't bother you in the
least though, you just went on and did it your
own way!"
Athanase stood up so as to gain in a hurry,
if necessary, his chosen place. One never
knew what a spoil-sport like this would do.
"What's your name?" he asked the man
whose lips were again moving.
"Bagu."
"Bagu!" I'm not surprised! It's elegance
itself, just like you and your manners!"
Bagu, with his thin face and hungry eyes,
looked like a workman who had been out of
employment for a long time.
"Why suicide, may I ask?"
'Poverty!"
Athanase de Glidoir raised his chin in the
air the least bit in the world:
"Idiot!" he said. "Poverty's no reason for
killing yourself; it's a reason for living, the
best, the only reason! If you possess nothing
it's exactly as though you were just born,
everything is before you to desire, to conquer
and to take. Now the only logical reason for
suicide is riches, because there's no cure for
it. A rich man is a sort of dead-alive person.
He has no destination, nothing to desire,
nothing to discover. At least you have the
excuse of loneliness."

down low and swallowing an opium pill.
Unfortunately his excitement w or ked
against the narcotic and so after half an hour
he was wide enough awake to hear the door of

Instantly his desire for death took unto itself wings, and he was seized with a love of
life, so acute that his most insignificant possessions seemed dear past telling. He jumped
out of bed, and as Bagu got to the door of
the room, creeping noiselessly along, he

"Stop! It's I. You recognize me, don't
you? I did think I'd like to die, and it was

But Bagu turned up the lamp and advanced
impeturbably. The absinthe drunk after a
long fast, had taken effect, and he loomed up
sinister and formidable. His voice sounded
solemn.
"Oh! yes, I recognize you, but that's not

"What!" cried de Glidoir, backing to the

He moved a chair quietly to the bed, like a

De Glidoir shrivelled up in the bed-clothes.

"Very well, I'll allow you to steal a little

Athanase's eyes were starting from his head

"You'll never be able to find :the money—
here, let me.get up—"
"Oh! don't bother; I've got all the time
there is. I can hunt for it all night if
necessary."
The knife was ready, wide open.

"I have two children."
"Mercy on us! What next? I've a good
notion to hang you up again with my own
hands! Why this is worse than mere stupidity,
it's a criminal monstrosity, your committing

De Glidoir pronounced these last words with

idea of hanging himself now, possibly from

Bagu
This was a happy thought, and quite satisfied his desire for a dramatic exit, and along
with it he could do a stroke of charity. Yes,
indeed, it was a good idea all around.
He helped the man to his feet, and taking
hold of his arm he walked him along slowly,
giving him a little shake every now and then
to complete his resuscitation, talking to him
persuasively all the time.
"You go to the Rue de Prony, number 208.
On the ground floor to the right, a man, lives
who goes to bed every night at nine o'clock,
dead drunk, with his door-key on the outside.
He's rich and you can make a fine haul there,
but I'd begin by cutting his throat if I were
you, because he's a low blackguard with no
sympathy for the poor, and besides, he always
keeps a revolver under his pillow and he's had
alarms put on all his drawers."
They were just passing a cutler's shop, so
Athanase went in and bought him a fine clasp
knife.
"Put that in your pocket," he said to Bagu,
who obeyed him with the impassive stare
of a sleep-walker.
"Let's go to a cafe."
Athenase poured absinthe and seltzer into
the man until you'd have thought he'd burst.
"Now, there you are," he said, leaving
him, "you'd best go directly. Remember
your poor children, and do not hesitate!"

with the tone of authority of a superior person,
speaking to some ignorant insignificant, he
said:
"Monsieur, I possess nothing, it's with me
exactly as though I had just been born, everything is before me,—to desire, to conquer and
to taste—"
De Glidoir gave a hideous grimace which he
fondly believe to be a smile.
"Come, come, Bagu, I'm a good sort of a
chap—"
"You? Why, you're a low blackguard with
no sympathy for the poor!"
"Well, then, take my gold watch. Will
that satisfy you? It's there on the chimneypiece."
With his armed hand Bagu made a dignified
gesture.
"I have children," he said. "I belong to
them."
De Glidoir began to sob.
"I cut you down when you'd hanged yourself, and saved your life! Was ever such ingratitude!"
The same gesture of offended dignity from
Bagu.
"Monsieur," he said, "I am convinced that
I am doing you a service: being rich, you are
a sort of dead-alive person with no destination,
nothing to desire, nothing to discover—Don't
take on so. I won't hurt you much. I know
how to do it, because I've cut ducks' throats
for years."
So saying, Bagu again passed and repassed
the blade over his arm to give it a final edge,
and then stood up.

Athancase, wild with terror and scarcely
knowing what he was doing, cried out in a
loud voice as though it were absolutely necessary for him to know before he died:
"And—your children—are they girls or
boys!"
Bagu stopped sharpening the knife, but he
turned up his sleeve in a business-like way:
"Two girls: Marie and Je'anne."
Athanase, with an idiotic bleat, went on:
"Ah, that's much better than boys!"
"Ye, much better," answered Bagu distantly, rubbing his thumb along the edge of
the blade.

7

"I'm so fond of children," brayed de
Glidoir, squinting at the knife as though his
visitor were about to dispatch a brace of
cherubim for,his consumption.
Bagu shrngged his shoulders approvingly.
'I have their pictures somewhere,' he said.
"I brought them with me to kiss them farewell."
"Oh! do let me see them!" begged de
Glidoir.
"There," said Bagu, taking a small photograph from an inside pocket.
Athanase seized on it and giving an absurdly forced laugh, cried;
"Ah! You said Marie and Jeanne, didn't
you? This must be Marie, the elder. She's
pretty, but Jeanne, she looks like a sly little
piece!"
"She is that!" replied Bagu, beginning to
be interested, "you can ask anyone in the
neighborhood."
"I simply can't take my eyes off them!"
cried de Glidoir, "they're just the kind of
children I adore!"
Bagu gave a deprecating smile and began
again to strop the knife, this time on his
thigh. The gentleman's demonstrations
seemed perfectly natural to him.
"Could you possibly give me this photograph?" asked de Glidoir, with the avidity of
a lover.
Bagu's smile broadened. He was rather
tickled at the idea. "Proud Papa," that sort
of thing. Instantly, though, his expression
changed as though the smile had been stopped
by a ratchet. He stood with his mouth open
like one hypnotized by some terrible, unheard
of difficulty. He looked first at the knife and
then at Athanase; one could'nt give photographs to a dead man.
"I'd like, to," he said in an embarassed
tone, "but—," and he stopped, confused by
the dilemma between which he was caught.
"Oh, come now," said de Glidoir, understanding the situation perfectly. He did not
offer to solve the problem, however, but
studied the picture minutely.
"I've never seen such interesting children's
faces," he went on. `Ah! little Marie—and
Jeanne—really, it,s awfully hard to decide
which—they're both so—!"

THE NEWS-LETTER.

He pronounced the words with the deepest
interest and respect. Bagu stood smiling,
pleased and paternal. Then he again grew
grave. What was he to do? He was caught
in a tight place between the poignard and the
portrait. He gave another smile:
"No, Monsieur, you have never seen two
such little beauties,"
Again, he busied himself with the knife.
Whatever was he to do? It was a simple
matter enough to kill this gentleman and
make away with everything he had of any
value, but on the other hand, it seemed a
pity to cut the throat of anyone who had such
obviously good taste.
Finally vanity came out the stronger. He
could not do away with such a keen
appreciator of his children's beauty.
"Very well," he said, "you may keep the
picture."
He closed the knife, put it in his hip pocket
and got up with the air of a casual visitor
taking his leave.
"Ah!" said de Glidoir, embarassed apparently at accepting the gift, "I really hardly
like to deprive you—"
"Oh! don't mention it, don't mention it,"
said Bagu with a wave of his hand.
And in order to cut short these formalities,
he walked toward the door. His role of
father of the two charming daughters made
him the equal of this admiring gentleman
and compelled him to noble manners.
He had forgotten the possibilty of taking
anything of the least value. His poverty was
forgotten and every reality became negligible.
He was enriched to infinity by paternal
vanity.
He went out, his bosom sweling with pride,
making the same gesture of a gentleman
deprecating a trifling service done for another.
Some people passing, were rather astonished
at the grand manner with which he said:
"Not at all! not at all!" as he closed the
door.
A lot is heard 'bout Presidents,
The party's love for Taft;
We wonder if this match will bring
To both an Eppie-Taft.

This "contribution" (of which genus the smallest

following note:
To the Editor of the NEWS-LliTTER:
Dear Sir:—This is a contribution from one who
is very much interested in the NUN/vs-LATTER—an

Undergrad, not a Post-Grad.

Whirr-bang! The door-bell had hardly
stopped ringing when the staid old butler
threw open the door and in walked the flurried
and anxious Post-Grad. Staggered by the
shining silver card tray, he lunged into his
pocket with a desperate gasp in search of the
elusive pasteboard. Where on earth was it?
What made the butler smile in that supercilious way? Why, he had had the card as he
came up the steps, and now—and now—good
gracious!—it was in his left hand! The supercilious smile broadened into an open grin,as the
dignified white shirt front bowed him into the
parlor. He stepped gingerly over the slippery
floor, glancing hopelessly at the spindlelegged gilt chairs and remained standing in
the middle of the floor. A deliciously dainty
rustle of silk, the clicking of tiny French
heels on the stair—there she stood in the
doorway, a vision of fur and feathers, her
long, dark cloak in marked contrast with her
delicate pink cheeks.
The Post-Grad took three hasty steps, but
alas!—that slippery floor! The table—the
chair—what COULD he grasp? What—but
now it was too late—his heels slipped, and the
dignified student of philosophy sprawled in a
helpless tangle with the slender legs of the
gilded chair.
At last he arose to his feet and, blushing
furiously, stammered: 'Er—ah—isn't it a
nice day for the game?" The girl, sweetly
ignoring the mishap, but inwardly choking
with laughter, led the way to the door, and
together they walked down the steps and
silently hurried to the car.
"We must be exceedingly early," the PostGrad remarked, as they took their seats.
"Yes," said the girl, "nobody seems to be
going to the game. Who's going to play,
anyhow?"
"Well, you see, er—every year they play,
you know, er —that is, the Freshman and

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Junior contingents choose ah—eleven men to
determine—ah, to decide—I mean to play
football."
"Oh how perfectly lovely! I wish I understood it as well as you do! But, of course,
you have played so often."
"Ah—well; no—that is—not exactly. I
received an injury—ah—during the early—in
the first part of my Freshman year, and have
never—really played since."
"Oh, how terrible!" came the sympathetic
cry.
"Ah, don't worry, not seriously you know
—just ah—only—well you see—I sprained
my little finger—"
Whereupon the girl coughed suddenly and
looked out the window.
After a long and embarassing silence, the
car stopped and the Post-Grad rose.
"Here's where we get out," he said.
"Do we have to walk far?" she asked.
(Ah—er I don't know—I should have inquired more particularily as to the way, but I
think—ah—now I remember—we go over
there.
Together they walked silently across the
road, down the path, and over the bridge.
"I don't see a single soul. We must be
very early—there's no one here at all," and
she looked dolefully, first at the vast stretches
of mud, and then at her mud-bespattered
shoes.
"I will get my tickets out anyhow," and
the serious student extricated the tickets from
the depths of his costume and began to peruse
them slowly. Suddenly he stopped, gasped
and cried,
'What—what day is today?"
``The fifth."
"Well—it's—the—wrong—day."
M. M. G.

ATHLETIC NOTES.
Again has the Lacrosse Team of 1902 come
to the fore and offered to the Junior and Freshman Classes a set of individual trophies to be
contested for by lacrosse teams from those
classes. This is the third year that these
trophies have been offered, and they have been
productive of some excellent games. Last
year the contests were not so interesting as the
year before, when the present Senior Class,
then Freshmen, took the class of 1907 into
camp in the two games played.
The generosity and spirit of the men who
compose the team of 1902 is certainly to be
commended, and it is to be hoped that the
classes this year will show the proper appreciation of such a generous gift. It is a good
showing for the spirit among our alumni,
when, in addition to contributions toward an
athletic field, they can subscribe to foster the
lacrosse spirit at the University. The NEWSLETTER takes great pleasure in thanking the
1902 team for their exceedingly kind offer on
behalf of the students of the University.
The Director of the Gymnasium has undertaken a worthy project, and one in which all
the fellows should heartily co-operate. The
scheme is to supply those who use the shower
baths with clean towels whenever wanted, at
a cost price. He has gotten an appropriation
from the Board of Trustees, and with it will
purchase 1,000 bath towels. Now the plan is
this: Each fellow who wants a towel is to
sign a card and pay a dollar. He may either
pay a dollar in advance, or it may be taken off
his caution money at the end of the year: that
point has not been settled as yet. By paying
this dollar, he is entitled to a clean towel
whenever he may wish it. This privilege will
continue from now until the University
closes. This is an excellent plan, and will
do away with lots of trouble. Instead of
having to bring towels from home, or rent
them from "Jim," a man may have a clean
towel whenever he wishes, at the low cost of
one dollar for five months. This one dollar
represents the cost of laundering. Now, in
order to make this scheme work, there must be
a big crowd in it. There must be at least 100
bathers sign up for the towels. If the plan
works, and it certainly ought if the students

10

THE NEWS-LETTER.

give it the proper backing, Dr. Abercrombie
is to be congratulated, for he will have supplied a long-felt want, and added one more
comfort to the locker room.

LACROSSE TEAM.
The lacrosse season is in full blast, and
soon you will see the usual number of swollen
fingers, and cut heads as a result of practising
in the cage. The prospects for a winning
team are good, but there are several positions
yet to be filled. From time to time the daily
newspapers have come out with fore-casts of
what the line-up will be. To the candidates
let this be said: Pay no attention to what the
papers say, for they are usually far from
right, particularly with regard to Hopkins
teams. There is some time yet before the
first game, and surprises are likely to happen
at any time. Sometimes fellows do not make
the team until the last game, so keep your
nerve with you. Remember the class teams.
If you play on the winning class team, you
will get a fine gold medal. Juniors, you have
not won at lacrosse as yet, and you can't
afford to be beaten by the Freshmen. Freshmen, you were beaten in football, now get
busy and retrieve yourselves by licking the
Juniors in lacrosse. It has been done before,
and can be done again.
This year the Lacrosse League, in addition
to giving a trophy to the winning team, will
give individual trophies to the players on
championship teams. Hopkins must win the
championship, and everybody must do his
best to land that coveted title. Let us see if
the team of 1908 can't be the one to make it
three championships straight.

COTILLON CLUB.
The time for the next Cotillon Club Dance
is almost here, and there are many subscribers
who have not yet paid anything on their dues,
not even for the first dance. This state of
affairs is positively disgraceful. How do you
expect us to give these dances in the proper
style? You do not seem to realize that it
takes ready money to run these dances, and
unless one hundred dollars more is paid up it

will be impossible to give the other two
dances. The Board .of Governors is working
as hard as it possibly can to collect the money,
but it met with very little success before the
Christmas Holidays. Let us hope that it will
be more successful in the New Year. Everyone before Christmas was crying hard times,
but now that it is past and everyone received
lots of money at Christmas, there is no excuse
for not paying.
The Cotillon Club Dances are not supported
by the students as well as they should be. It
used to be that everyone was anxious to
attend the Cotillons, and did not have to be
begged to come. When one remembers that
the Cotillon Club Dances—and there are only
three during the year—are the only social
activity at Hopkins, one ought to feel ashamed
to think that the students have to be beseached
and implored to subscribe to the dances, and
even then enough subscriptions can not be
raised to insure the success of the dances.
The three upper classes are well represented
more or less, but the Freshmen did not make
as good a showing as was expected of them.
Freshmen, it is no excuse to say that you are
too busy, or have too much work, for both of
the remaining dances are on Friday nights.
Another point is that we will not have the
tone of these dances lowered. All the gentlemen are requested to wear either tuxedos or
full dress. We think that only a word on
this subject will be sufficient.
We should like to take this opportunity to
remark upon the lack of interest which is
shown by the chaperons in the dances. There
is always a list of about twenty-five chaperons
on the programs, but usually there are present
only about three or at the most five. These
are generally the same ones and we take
great pleasure in extending to them our
heartiest thanks, and hope that they will continue to take interest in the dances. What a
dreadful plight we should be in, if the few
faithful ones should ever desert us!
